SC Elections •

Two final candidates for Student Council President will be selected from a list of five
candidates during primary elections this week. Next year's S.C. Vice-President,
Secretary, and two final candidates for Treasurer will also be elected.
Run-off elections to determine next year's Student Council President and Treasurer
Will take place next week between the two top vote-getters in this week's election,
unless one candidate gets a majority this week.
Dave Chesanow, Stuart Davidson, Bunny Howard, Gary Stahl, and Brad Stark are the
candidates for S.C. President.
Chesanow based his campaign on the theme of revitalizing student government. He
called this year's S.C. "an absurdity", "a joke", and "a high school, not a college
student government." Chesanow is aligned with Andy Albstein, a Vice-Presidential
Candidate.
David son mentioned financial aid, tuition increases, the bookstore, and
undergraduate housing as major issues for the election. "The student government has
the momentum to effect changes," he claimed, as a result of its recent successful battle
against the calendar change. He emphasized experience as one of his best assets, citing
his membership on the Education Committee and the Issues Committee of the Student
Council.
The proposed change in the Maryland drinking age to 21, the undergraduate housing
Shortage, and high costs in the bookstore were noted by Howard in her campaign. She
called for a "coalition between students and faculty" to prevent future incidents like
the calendar change. She also urged procedural changes within the Student Council to
make it more "time efficient".
Stahl criticized this year's student council for "disappearing". He placed top priority
on re-establishing a rapport between the council and the student body. He advocated
setting up a bookstore co-op similar to those at Harvard and Yale, and publishing a
housing rating to inform students about, the quality of area housing. Stahl offered his
experience managing the Rathskellar as evidence that he is capable of coordinating the
social calendars of the Student Council, the Rathskellar, and fraternities.
Two major issues cited by Stark were academics and the Student Council itself. He
noted decisions made yesterday by the Committee of Undergraduate Studies concerning
lntersession and a foreign language requirement as examples of major academic decision
made without student input. Deploring factions which have prevented the Student
Council from being united, he claimed that he possesses the administrative ability
necessary to organize it effectively.
Andy Albstein and Randy Randazzo are running for S.C. Vice-President. Albstein's
main plank was to "make the student union a union for students," assuring
undergraduates of first priority in the use of campus facilities. Randazzo stated he
Would attempt to attempt to attract a big name group such as Fleetwood Mac or Dave
Mason for a major concert at Homewood Field. •
Pat Gatling and Brian Stamp are the candidates for S.C. SecretarY. The position of
S.C. Treasurer has extra significance because it entails duties as chairman of the Student
Activities Commission. Val Fein, Dave Lewing, and Neal Pilzer are running for this
office.
Fein promised to bring the SAC under more Student Council control, if elected, in
order to create a unified student government. Lewing stated that he would work toward
a more equitable distribution of funds between SAC groups. Pilzer cited his experience
on the S.C. Housing Committee, the Admissions Office, and the Academic Ethics Board
as qualifications for the position.
-Robert Riggs

Your Bets

A few Saturdays ago Beta held its infamous party in the Great Hall (or, as they called
it, the Dryheave Lounge.) Last Friday two clowns performed in the Great Hall. And
Sunday evening, the candidates for that crucible of campus politics they call the
Student Council, took over the. Great Hall for a "forum" to inform the populus who
and what are running for office. Which again proves that the great monuments will
endure whatever atrocities inflicted upon them.
Introduced by a dapper Andy Davis, who as moderator, sported the coolest of
Oxfords, the candidates for the respective offices each spoke for a few minutes and then
were subjected to intense grilling by members of the audience. Unfortunately no
budding Joe Pynes or Mike Wallaces presented themselves as cavalier challengers, so the
candidates were merely allowed to rehash their opening remarks with flashes of
informality or personality rarely showing through. Over all it was a pretty dull affair,
but keeping with a general atmosphere of "no monkey business here—we've got work to
do.
Because the candidates for each office were presented alphabetically presidential
hopeful David Chesanow was the first to speak. The "spacey" personality evident in his
posters was nowhere to be found as he carefully read his prepared text. It was as if he
finally realized the seriousness of his campaign and felt he had to legitimize his
candidacy to the student council groupies and media representatives in the audience.
Chesanow's eyes were his most effective oratory device; calling the present council
"impotent" he stared at the accused with sarcasm and disgust. His leadership potential
seemed to take the form of what the Caribou Eskimos call ihumakortujok, wisdom of
non-shamanistic kind; he wants to remove the Student Council from the theatre of the
Absurd and move it into the old-fasioned Bijou where the audience can participate in
singalongs("Follow the bouncing ball") and dish giveaways.
_ The word buffo came to mind when Stuart Davidson performed his speech. In
person, Davidson is less the Wagnerian ubermensch of his posters and more the
intellectual Ralph Kramden. As he leaned on the lectern trying to project an image of
affability, Davidson came across as being a bit too slick for his own good. His speech
contained obviously polished and prepared phrases like "Student Talent Bank",
"defender of the student interest", and said he was sick of seeing students "pardon the
French, getting screwed." The smart money's on Davidson because of heavy student
politico backing, who always seem to get the necessary votes out of nowhere.
If the Good Lord had made Jimmy Carter a female, he would have been Bunny
Howard. One of her platform planks is a phone-in to the President every other week on
WJHU and she harps constantly on the inefficiency of present student government. Hers
is a no-nonsense campaign, a complete lack of ideology in favor of practicalities. She
seems to be very sincere in her intentions, but her main problem is, indeed, her name.
Can you imagine the head of the Student Government being called President Bunny?
Gary Stahl's too nice a guy to be involved in student politics. Like the other
candidates, his sincerity can not be doubted and he seems truly concerned with the
plight of the studentry.As manager of the Rathskellar, Gary knows what the social
needs of the community are and plans to center his administration around meeting the
students' everyday needs. Political tipsters rate Gary a longshot, which is too bad
considering he has the potential to inject new blood into the system.
Fortunately Brad Stark is far from his mythical namesake, Willy Stark in All the
King's Men. He seems to be the cerebral candidate of the bunch, the protege of George
McGovern. Brad's not a very exciting person; in fact he seems too business-like to rouse
the electorate in his favor. Like Gary Stahl, he's touted as a longshot, seen with little
chance with capturing the crown.
- Stretch Hogan

In a number of recent decisions, the
Burger Court has indeed severely limited

order metropolitan-wide solutions to
both inner-city desegregation and public
housing problems. Beginning with a 1974
Detroit decision, the Court has
substantially stiffened the nature of
evidence required for consolidation of
metropolitan governmental units. In
Milliken v. Bradley the Court ruled that a

The University Committee on Undergraduate Studies (CUS) voted 5-4 to abolish credit for intersession
courses yesterday.
An advisory committee to the Academic Counsel, comprised of five faculty members and four students,
all five CUS faculty members Voted for a voluntary, non-credited intersession, according to CUS student
representatives Alfredo Holt . and Vicki Shemin. The vote followed an oral presentation by Cathy
Michaelson, chairperson for the Student Council's Committee on Education. Michaelson and co-workers
recently released a report on intersession 1977, advocating a Continuation of the present 4-4-4 format.
The results of the vote are .not considered too surprising in lieu • of a poll of departmental chairmen
conducted last week which also called for the discontinuation of a credited interesession. But Michaelson
said,"This action by the faculty members of the committee illustrates the incredible insensitivity to
undergraduate needs."
Some students have suggested there is financial motivation for the administration's lack of support for
credited intersession. The administration Will not put pressure on the faculty to teach courses, because I
feel they are afraid that students will pick up intersession credits and graduate early," Michaelson said. Holt
said one faculty member indeed suggested that althoUgh students may be saving money by graduating early.

Holt and Shemin also questioned the fairness of the procedures .employed to discuss the intersession

conducted in one and a half hours, which is just not normal," Shemin said.

Greenmount Goodwill: The Price is Right
For the Hopkins' student seeking anything from
apartment furnishings to used clothes, the Waverly
Goodwill Thrift Store, at 3209 Greenmount Avenue,
offers a wide selection of quality merchandise.
Bedroom furnishings are the specialty of the Waverly
store; there are many repainted or revarnished 4 ft. high
bureaus and dressers available for $45 to $65, several 3'h
ft. repainted cabinets for $18—$22, and nightstands at
$10—$15. The most abundant item in stock is new
matresses and box springs, at an average cost of about $50
each.
Nevertheless, considering the mediocre-condition of the
merchandise, these prices seem exorbitant to some
people. When I asked a nearby shopper to take a shot at
some of the prices of the pieces, his guesses consistently
fell short of the actual cost. He guessed $35 for a dresser
that really cost $45; $50 for another dresser that was
marked at $65; and finally, when he discovered that a
desk which he estimated at $30 actually cost $78, he
remarked,"Whoa, that's a little bit outrageous."
In addition, sofas, loveseats, and chairs are priced
comparably. As for chairs, costs range from $10 for a
soiled corlo to $36 for a high-quality recliner. While
decadent sofas are on display for $40, a mere $85
investment will get you a new one. Love seats are all in
good condition and are priced at about $50.
In the Electrical Appliances section, good condition
electric coffee pots cost $8, $5-$8 will get one a decent
iron, frying pans are 8 bills, toasters go for about a fin,
and fair quality blenders cost $12-$15.

Several other customers though, claim that even these
prices are too high. One elderly lady said: "The big
problem is that there are no more sales; everything costs
the regular price. Look, over there, all dresses are
half-price, but nobody buys them because they were
overpriced in the beginning. I think that it is a little bit
ridiculous after all, if they had let the prices go a little bit
lower, they would make more profit. As it is it doesn't
help the poor people much because everybody's looking
to save money."
Despite such complaints, the wide selection of used
clothes, ranging from women's dresses to men's sport
coats still is priced practically dirt-cheap. Although much
of the women's attire is several years (if not several
decades) old, the average non-sale price for a dress is only
$3-$5, while $2-$3 will buy a pair of women's slacks.
Men's slacks also go for $2-$3, with some work pants
tossed in, while suit coats in wearable condition cost
$3-$5.
Yet, because many of the smaller items do not have
price tags, there was a belief among some of the shoppers
that the spot pricing at the sales counter was inequitable.
An older woman said: "I'll tell you one thing, if you
know someone at the cash register it's cheaper—they like
to charge more for someone they don't know. They
simply charge whatever they feel like charging on the
things that aren't marked. These things are nice if you
need them, but you have to get a grab at the things that
have tags."
When another senior citizen was asked about this, she

agreed: "That's right, they do charge a little more from
the people they don't know, because they think that they
have the money; it's natural, sure enough, but nowadays
nobody has the money. People come here to find nice
pieces—but the prices! They got all this stuff for
nothing—it should be cheaper. Still, we find good things
here."
However, the store manager, James Sutton Jr.,
maintains that he seldom gets complaints. "Sure, some
people who come in here want to spit in your face, but
you have to have common sense to work with the public.
Ninety-nine per cent of the people are pretty good. When
a customer pays you a compliment, that makes your
day—it makes you overlook when someone gives you a
hard way to go."
Similarly, Mr. Sutton is proud of Goodwill: "I think
that Goodwill is a fine organization because they do a
good service to the public. They help the people who
nobody else wants to help—they've put people back on
the streets, too. Here at Waverly we have a good business,
we have what the people are looking for. The thirteen
area Goodwill stores in the area had $1.5 million in
turnover last year, and this store alone accounted for
$98,000 of that. And I'd say that Johns Hopkins students
give me one quarter of all my sales."
In this frantic time for freshmen of apartment hunting,
the Waverly Goodwill might not be a bad place to drop by
and at least take a look at the goods. It isn't exactly Saks
Fifth Avenue, but it sure beats rummaging through your
neighbors' trash.

The Hopkins varsity ;lacrosse team tuned up for its
regular season opener this Saturday by thrashing the

The JHU-Penn scrimmage is an annual event, although

Last year, however, Hopkins had to come from behind to
nip the Quakers, 16-15, and another tight match was
expected this year.

Hopkins had trouble getting untracked in the opening
fifteen minutes and, had it not been for the hot-shooting
of Dave Huntley, JHU might have found itself on the
short end of the score.

offense in the first period. He scored three goals to give

minutes. Led by attackmen Mike O'Neill and Rich Hirsch
and goaltender Mike Federico, the Homewood stickmen
pumped six unanswered goals into the Quaker net and
effectively ended any doubt as to the ultimate outcome
of the contest.
O'Neill had a pair of goals, including one scored while
lying on the ground, while Hirsch chipped in with a goal
and an assist. Federico, a freshman from Baltimore, was
subbing in the nets for the injured Kevin Mahon and did
an excellent job against whatever offense Penn could
muster.
The Jays total domination of play continued through
the third period. The Hopkins attack wasted little time
building on their 9-2 halftime lead, while the Blue Jay
backline effectively halted the Quaker offensive thrusts.
Freshman Jon Swerdloff, battling for the final starting
at6ck position (Hirsch and O'Neill have locked up the
other two slots), opened the second half scoring after
taking a pass from Joe Garavante on a two-on-one fast
break. Swerdloff's short shot past the helpless Penn

netminer gave the Jays a 10-2 advantage.

A few Saturdays ago Beta held its infamous party in the Great Hall (or, as they called
it, the Dryheave Lounge.) Last Friday two clowns performed in the Great Hall. And
Sunday evening, the candidates for that crucible of campus politics they call the
Student Council, took over the. Great Hall for a "forum" to inform the populus who
and what are running for office. Which again proves that the great monuments will
endure whatever atrocities inflicted upon them.
Introduced by a dapper Andy Davis, who as moderator, sported the coolest of
Oxfords, the candidates for the respective offices each spoke for a few minutes and then
were subjected to intense grilling by members of the audience. Unfortunately no
budding Joe Pynes or Mike Wallaces presented themselves as cavalier challengers, so the
candidates were merely allowed to rehash their opening remarks with flashes of
informality or personality rarely showing through. Over all it was a pretty dull affair,
but keeping with a general atmosphere of "no monkey business here—we've got work to
do.
Because the candidates for each office were presented alphabetically presidential
hopeful David Chesanow was the first to speak. The "spacey" personality evident in his
posters was nowhere to be found as he carefully read his prepared text. It was as if he
finally realized the seriousness of his campaign and felt he had to legitimize his
candidacy to the student council groupies and media representatives in the audience.
Chesanow's eyes were his most effective oratory device; calling the present council
"impotent" he stared at the accused with sarcasm and disgust. His leadership potential
seemed to take the form of what the Caribou Eskimos call ihumakortujok, wisdom of
non-shamanistic kind; he wants to remove the Student Council from the theatre of the
Absurd and move it into the old-fasioned Bijou where the audience can participate in
singalongs("Follow the bouncing ball") and dish giveaways.
_ The word buffo came to mind when Stuart Davidson performed his speech. In
person, Davidson is less the Wagnerian ubermensch of his posters and more the
intellectual Ralph Kramden. As he leaned on the lectern trying to project an image of
affability, Davidson came across as being a bit too slick for his own good. His speech
contained obviously polished and prepared phrases like "Student Talent Bank",
"defender of the student interest", and said he was sick of seeing students "pardon the
French, getting screwed." The smart money's on Davidson because of heavy student
politico backing, who always seem to get the necessary votes out of nowhere.
If the Good Lord had made Jimmy Carter a female, he would have been Bunny
Howard. One of her platform planks is a phone-in to the President every other week on
WJHU and she harps constantly on the inefficiency of present student government. Hers
is a no-nonsense campaign, a complete lack of ideology in favor of practicalities. She
seems to be very sincere in her intentions, but her main problem is, indeed, her name.
Can you imagine the head of the Student Government being called President Bunny?
Gary Stahl's too nice a guy to be involved in student politics. Like the other
candidates, his sincerity can not be doubted and he seems truly concerned with the
plight of the studentry.As manager of the Rathskellar, Gary knows what the social
needs of the community are and plans to center his administration around meeting the
students' everyday needs. Political tipsters rate Gary a longshot, which is too bad
considering he has the potential to inject new blood into the system.
Fortunately Brad Stark is far from his mythical namesake, Willy Stark in All the
King's Men. He seems to be the cerebral candidate of the bunch, the protege of George
McGovern. Brad's not a very exciting person; in fact he seems too business-like to rouse
the electorate in his favor. Like Gary Stahl, he's touted as a longshot, seen with little
chance with capturing the crown.

Greenmount Goodwill: The Price is Right
For the Hopkins' student seeking anything from
apartment furnishings to used clothes, the Waverly
Goodwill Thrift Store, at 3209 Greenmount Avenue,
offers a wide selection of quality merchandise.
Bedroom furnishings are the specialty of the Waverly
store; there are many repainted or revarnished 4 ft. high
bureaus and dressers available for $45 to $65, several 3'h
ft. repainted cabinets for $18—$22, and nightstands at
$10—$15. The most abundant item in stock is new
matresses and box springs, at an average cost of about $50
each.
Nevertheless, considering the mediocre-condition of the
merchandise, these prices seem exorbitant to some
people. When I asked a nearby shopper to take a shot at
some of the prices of the pieces, his guesses consistently
fell short of the actual cost. He guessed $35 for a dresser
that really cost $45; $50 for another dresser that was
marked at $65; and finally, when he discovered that a
desk which he estimated at $30 actually cost $78, he
remarked,"Whoa, that's a little bit outrageous."
In addition, sofas, loveseats, and chairs are priced
comparably. As for chairs, costs range from $10 for a
soiled corlo to $36 for a high-quality recliner. While
decadent sofas are on display for $40, a mere $85
investment will get you a new one. Love seats are all in
good condition and are priced at about $50.
In the Electrical Appliances section, good condition
electric coffee pots cost $8, $5-$8 will get one a decent
iron, frying pans are 8 bills, toasters go for about a fin,
and fair quality blenders cost $12-$15.

Several other customers though, claim that even these
prices are too high. One elderly lady said: "The big
problem is that there are no more sales; everything costs
the regular price. Look, over there, all dresses are
half-price, but nobody buys them because they were
overpriced in the beginning. I think that it is a little bit
ridiculous after all, if they had let the prices go a little bit
lower, they would make more profit. As it is it doesn't
help the poor people much because everybody's looking
to save money."
Despite such complaints, the wide selection of used
clothes, ranging from women's dresses to men's sport
coats still is priced practically dirt-cheap. Although much
of the women's attire is several years (if not several
decades) old, the average non-sale price for a dress is only
$3-$5, while $2-$3 will buy a pair of women's slacks.
Men's slacks also go for $2-$3, with some work pants
tossed in, while suit coats in wearable condition cost
$3-$5.
Yet, because many of the smaller items do not have
price tags, there was a belief among some of the shoppers
that the spot pricing at the sales counter was inequitable.
An older woman said: "I'll tell you one thing, if you
know someone at the cash register it's cheaper—they like
to charge more for someone they don't know. They
simply charge whatever they feel like charging on the
things that aren't marked. These things are nice if you
need them, but you have to get a grab at the things that
have tags."
When another senior citizen was asked about this, she

agreed: "That's right, they do charge a little more from
the people they don't know, because they think that they
have the money; it's natural, sure enough, but nowadays
nobody has the money. People come here to find nice
pieces—but the prices! They got all this stuff for
nothing—it should be cheaper. Still, we find good things
here."
However, the store manager, James Sutton Jr.,
maintains that he seldom gets complaints. "Sure, some
people who come in here want to spit in your face, but
you have to have common sense to work with the public.
Ninety-nine per cent of the people are pretty good. When
a customer pays you a compliment, that makes your
day—it makes you overlook when someone gives you a
hard way to go."
Similarly, Mr. Sutton is proud of Goodwill: "I think
that Goodwill is a fine organization because they do a
good service to the public. They help the people who
nobody else wants to help—they've put people back on
the streets, too. Here at Waverly we have a good business,
we have what the people are looking for. The thirteen
area Goodwill stores in the area had $1.5 million in
turnover last year, and this store alone accounted for
$98,000 of that. And I'd say that Johns Hopkins students
give me one quarter of all my sales."
In this frantic time for freshmen of apartment hunting,
the Waverly Goodwill might not be a bad place to drop by
and at least take a look at the goods. It isn't exactly Saks
Fifth Avenue, but it sure beats rummaging through your
neighbors' trash.

The Hopkins varsity ;lacrosse team tuned up for its
regular season opener this Saturday by thrashing the
stickmen from the University of Pennsylvania, 17-7, this
past Saturday on the Quakers home field in Philadelphia.
The JHU-Penn scrimmage is an annual event, although
the Philadelphians have not defeated the Jays since 1974.
Last year, however, Hopkins had to come from behind to
nip the Quakers, 16-15, and another tight match was
expected this year.
The game was close-for the first quarter, at least.
Hopkins had trouble getting untracked in the opening
fifteen minutes and, had it not been for the hot-shooting
of Dave Huntley, JHU might have found itself on the
short end of the score.
Huntley, a sophomore midfielder, was the Blue Jay
offense in the first period. He scored three goals to give
the sluggish Jays a 3-2 lead going into the second quarter.
Fortunately, JHU woke up during the following fifteen
minutes. Led by attackmen Mike O'Neill and Rich Hirsch
and goaltender Mike Federico, the Homewood stickmen
pumped six unanswered goals into the Quaker net and
effectively ended any doubt as to the ultimate outcome
of the contest.
O'Neill had a pair of goals, including one scored while
lying on the ground, while Hirsch chipped in with a goal
and an assist. Federico, a freshman from Baltimore, was
subbing in the nets for the injured Kevin Mahon and did
an excellent job against whatever offense Penn could
muster.
The Jays total domination of play continued through
the third period. The Hopkins attack wasted little time
building on their 9-2 halftime lead, while the Blue Jay
backline effectively halted the Quaker offensive thrusts.
Freshman Jon Swerdloff, battling for the final starting
at6ck position (Hirsch and O'Neill have locked up the
other two slots), opened the second half scoring after
taking a pass from Joe Garavante on a two-on-one fast
break. Swerdloff's short shot past the helpless Penn

netminer gave the Jays a 10-2 advantage.
Penn finally remembered where the offensive end of
the field was and decided to see what it would be like if
they moved the play there. After several minutes of
pressure against an inexperienced Jay defense and a new
goaltender (Jay Trainor) the Quakers finally scored their
first goal since midway through the opening quarter.
